title: Isaiah Chapter 56 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 56 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 56 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 56.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 56:1, what does the LORD command to be kept?
questions.correctAnswer: Judgment and justice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:1 states, 'Keep ye judgment, and do justice.'

questions.question: Who is described as blessed in Isaiah 56:2?
options: The man that keeps the sabbath and does no evil
questions.correctAnswer: The man that keeps the sabbath and does no evil
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:2 blesses the man who keeps the sabbath from polluting it and refrains from doing evil.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 56:3 says the son of the stranger is separated from God's people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:3 states that the son of the stranger should not say he is separated from God's people.

questions.question: What will the LORD give to the eunuchs who keep His sabbaths, according to Isaiah 56:5?
options: A place and an everlasting name
questions.correctAnswer: A place and an everlasting name
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:5 says God will give eunuchs a place and a name better than sons and daughters, an everlasting name.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 56:6, who are included among those that join themselves to the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Sons of the stranger
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:6 mentions sons of the stranger who join themselves to the LORD to serve Him and keep the sabbath.

questions.question: What will God's house be called, according to Isaiah 56:7?
options: A house of prayer for all people
A place of sacrifice only for Israel
questions.correctAnswer: A house of prayer for all people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:7 states that God's house will be called a house of prayer for all people.

questions.question: Who does the LORD say He will gather besides those already gathered in Isaiah 56:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Others besides those gathered
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:8 mentions God will gather others in addition to those already gathered.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 56:10 describes the watchmen as alert and vigilant.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:10 describes the watchmen as blind, ignorant, dumb dogs who cannot bark and love to slumber.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 56:11, what kind of dogs are the watchmen compared to?
options: Greedy dogs which can never have enough
questions.correctAnswer: Greedy dogs which can never have enough
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:11 calls the watchmen greedy dogs that never have enough and shepherds that cannot understand.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 56:12: 'Come ye, say they, I will fetch ______, and we will fill ourselves with strong drink.'
questions.correctAnswer: wine
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:12 states, 'I will fetch wine, and we will fill ourselves with strong drink.'

questions.question: What does Isaiah 56:2 say a blessed man does with his hand?
questions.correctAnswer: Keeps it from doing evil
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:2 says a blessed man keeps his hand from doing any evil.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 56:4, what must eunuchs do to receive God's promise?
options: Keep the sabbaths and choose things that please God
questions.correctAnswer: Keep the sabbaths and choose things that please God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:4 says eunuchs who keep God's sabbaths and choose pleasing things will receive His promise.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 56:9 calls upon all beasts of the field to come and devour.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:9 says, 'All ye beasts of the field, come to devour.'

questions.question: Who are called 'shepherds that cannot understand' in Isaiah 56:11?
questions.correctAnswer: The watchmen
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:11 describes watchmen as greedy dogs and shepherds that cannot understand.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 56:7 say about the offerings of those who join themselves to the LORD?
options: Their burnt offerings and sacrifices shall be accepted
Only their prayers will be accepted
They must offer gold and silver
questions.correctAnswer: Their burnt offerings and sacrifices shall be accepted
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:7 states that their burnt offerings and sacrifices shall be accepted on God's altar.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 56 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 56 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 56:1 teach us about living with integrity in our work and daily responsibilities?
options: By keeping judgment and doing justice because God's salvation is near
By focusing on wealth and personal gain
By avoiding difficult decisions to maintain peace
By ignoring God's commandments to fit in with others
questions.correctAnswer: By keeping judgment and doing justice because God's salvation is near
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:1 commands us to keep judgment and do justice, reminding believers that God's salvation and righteousness are near. This teaches the importance of integrity and justice in daily life, supported further by verses 6 and 11 which speak against selfish gain and call for covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to maintain spiritual discipline. Based on Isaiah 56:2, what biblical truth would you share about honoring God?
options: Blessed is the man who keeps the Sabbath and refrains from evil
Blessed is the man who ignores religious rules
Blessed is the man who pursues wealth first
Blessed is the man who isolates himself from others
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed is the man who keeps the Sabbath and refrains from evil
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:2 highlights the blessing on those who keep the Sabbath without polluting it and who keep their hands from doing evil, emphasizing the importance of obedience and holiness in spiritual discipline. This is echoed in verses 4-6 about choosing what pleases God and holding fast to His covenant.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 56:3-5 encourage believers who feel excluded or less valued in the community of faith?
options: God promises eunuchs who keep His Sabbaths a place and an everlasting name
God excludes strangers and eunuchs from His blessings
Only those born into the community will receive God's favor
God favors only those who are physically strong and healthy
questions.correctAnswer: God promises eunuchs who keep His Sabbaths a place and an everlasting name
questions.explanation: Verses 3-5 assure that those who feel separated, like eunuchs or strangers, are not excluded from God's people if they keep His Sabbaths and covenant. God promises them a better place and an everlasting name, demonstrating His inclusive grace and faithfulness.

questions.question: What biblical principle about church fellowship and prayer is taught in Isaiah 56:6-7?
options: God's house is a house of prayer for all people, including strangers who serve Him
Only native-born Israelites may worship in God's house
Worship is limited to burnt offerings and sacrifices only
Prayer is unnecessary if one keeps the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: God's house is a house of prayer for all people, including strangers who serve Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:6-7 teaches that those who join themselves to the LORD, including strangers who keep the Sabbath and hold fast to the covenant, are welcomed to God's holy mountain and house of prayer, emphasizing inclusivity in worship and the importance of prayer as a communal practice.

questions.question: A believer feels isolated from God's people because of their background. What encouragement does Isaiah 56:8 provide?
options: God gathers not only Israel's outcasts but others besides them
God only gathers those born in Israel
God has abandoned those outside the covenant
God's gathering is limited to a select few
questions.correctAnswer: God gathers not only Israel's outcasts but others besides them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:8 reveals God's intention to gather both Israel's outcasts and others beyond Israel, showing His plan for a broad, inclusive community, encouraging believers that their background does not exclude them from God's family.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 56:9-11 warn church leaders about their responsibilities?
options: Watchmen are blind and dumb dogs who fail to protect and guide
Leaders are praised for their vigilance and selflessness
Watchmen are encouraged to seek their own gain
Leaders should avoid responsibilities to avoid mistakes
questions.correctAnswer: Watchmen are blind and dumb dogs who fail to protect and guide
questions.explanation: Verses 9-11 criticize leaders who are blind, ignorant, and selfish, likening them to dumb dogs that cannot bark to warn. This serves as a warning to church leaders to be vigilant, selfless, and faithful in their duties.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 56:12, what is the danger of leaders who prioritize their own pleasure over their duties?
options: They promote excessive drinking and neglect their responsibilities
They lead with wisdom and discipline
They seek justice and protect the vulnerable
questions.correctAnswer: They promote excessive drinking and neglect their responsibilities
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:12 describes leaders who invite others to drink wine and strong drink, indulging themselves and neglecting their duties, showing how selfishness and indulgence among leaders harm the community.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 56:2 teaches that keeping the Sabbath holy includes avoiding any evil actions.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:2 states that the blessed person keeps the Sabbath from polluting it and keeps their hands from doing any evil, linking Sabbath observance with moral conduct and obedience.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 56:7, God's house is intended only for the native-born Israelites to pray and worship.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:7 clearly says God's house shall be called a house of prayer for all people, including the sons of strangers who join themselves to the LORD, emphasizing inclusivity in worship.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 56:5 promises that eunuchs who keep God's Sabbaths and hold fast to His covenant will receive a place and a name ______ than that of sons and daughters.
questions.correctAnswer: better
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:5 promises eunuchs who keep the Sabbath and hold fast to the covenant a place and a name better than that of sons and daughters, assuring them of lasting honor and belonging.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 56:6 teach about the importance of love and service in the Christian community?
options: Strangers who join the LORD to serve Him and love His name are accepted
Service is optional and not connected to love
Only native-born Israelites can serve God
Love and service are separate from Sabbath observance
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers who join the LORD to serve Him and love His name are accepted
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:6 emphasizes that the sons of strangers who join the LORD to serve Him and love His name, keeping the Sabbath and holding fast to the covenant, are accepted, showing the inseparable link between love, service, and obedience.

questions.question: What biblical lesson about perseverance through trials can be drawn from Isaiah 56:4?
options: Eunuchs who choose to please God and keep His Sabbaths are honored
Only those without trials receive God's blessings
Trials are a sign of God's rejection
Ignoring God's covenant leads to blessings
questions.correctAnswer: Eunuchs who choose to please God and keep His Sabbaths are honored
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:4 encourages eunuchs who keep God's Sabbaths and choose what pleases Him, teaching perseverance and faithfulness through challenges results in honor and God's blessing.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 56:11 warn against selfishness in leadership and community life?
options: Leaders look to their own way and gain, not understanding their responsibility
Leaders serve selflessly and seek the good of all
Community life should focus on individual gain
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders look to their own way and gain, not understanding their responsibility
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:11 criticizes leaders who are greedy and selfish, looking only to their own gain, failing to understand their role to shepherd the people responsibly.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 56:7, what is the significance of burnt offerings and sacrifices in God's house?
options: They shall be accepted upon God's altar as part of joyful worship
They are no longer necessary and have been abolished
They are only for native-born Israelites
They are meaningless rituals without faith
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be accepted upon God's altar as part of joyful worship
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:7 teaches that burnt offerings and sacrifices of those who keep the Sabbath and hold fast to the covenant will be accepted on God's altar, showing the importance of sincere and joyful worship.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 56:10-11 imply about the consequences of spiritual neglect by leaders?
options: Blind and dumb watchmen fail to warn and lead the people properly
Leaders who neglect duties receive God's blessing
Spiritual neglect leads to community growth
Leaders who sleep on the job are rewarded
questions.correctAnswer: Blind and dumb watchmen fail to warn and lead the people properly
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:10-11 warns that leaders who are blind, ignorant, and silent like dumb dogs fail their duty to protect and guide the people, resulting in harm to the community.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 56 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 56.

questions.question: In Isaiah 56:1, what two actions does the LORD command before His salvation and righteousness are revealed?
options: Build an altar and offer sacrifices
Gather the people and sing praises
questions.correctAnswer: Keep judgment and do justice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:1 states, 'Keep ye judgment, and do justice: for my salvation is near to come, and my righteousness to be revealed.' This highlights the imperative to uphold justice before God's salvation.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 56:2, what is the condition for a man to be blessed?
options: He keeps the sabbath from polluting it and refrains from evil
He leads the people in worship
questions.correctAnswer: He keeps the sabbath from polluting it and refrains from evil
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:2 blesses the man who 'keepeth the sabbath from polluting it, and keepeth his hand from doing any evil,' emphasizing Sabbath observance and moral behavior.

questions.question: Isaiah 56:3 addresses the son of the stranger who joins himself to the LORD. What discouraged thought does the LORD disallow?
options: That he is utterly separated from God's people
That he is unworthy to pray
That he must leave his homeland
questions.correctAnswer: That he is utterly separated from God's people
questions.explanation: The verse discourages the foreigner from feeling isolated, saying, 'Neither let the son of the stranger... say, The LORD hath utterly separated me from his people,' emphasizing inclusivity.

questions.question: Who are specifically promised a place and an everlasting name in God's house according to Isaiah 56:5?
options: Eunuchs who keep the sabbath and take hold of God's covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Eunuchs who keep the sabbath and take hold of God's covenant
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:5 promises eunuchs who honor God's sabbath and covenant 'a place and a name better than of sons and of daughters' in God's house, showing divine inclusion.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'house of prayer for all people' mentioned in Isaiah 56:7?
options: It foreshadows the inclusive worship in the New Testament
It refers only to the temple in Jerusalem
It is a metaphor for the nation of Israel alone
It only applies to the descendants of Abraham
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the inclusive worship in the New Testament
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:7 states God's house 'shall be called an house of prayer for all people,' broadening the covenant community and prefiguring universal access to God as seen in the New Testament.

questions.question: In Isaiah 56:8, besides gathering Israel's outcasts, whom else does the LORD say He will gather?
questions.correctAnswer: Others besides those already gathered
questions.explanation: Verse 8 indicates a gathering beyond Israel's outcasts: 'Yet will I gather others to him, beside those that are gathered unto him,' suggesting a wider scope of salvation.

questions.question: How are the watchmen described in Isaiah 56:10, and what does this metaphor imply about their spiritual condition?
options: Blind, ignorant, dumb dogs who cannot bark
questions.correctAnswer: Blind, ignorant, dumb dogs who cannot bark
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:10 uses a metaphor of 'blind' and 'dumb dogs' to depict watchmen who are spiritually blind and ineffective, unable to warn or protect, indicating leadership failure.

questions.question: What characterizes the shepherds mentioned in Isaiah 56:11, and how does this reflect their leadership failure?
options: They are greedy and look only to their own gain
questions.correctAnswer: They are greedy and look only to their own gain
questions.explanation: Verse 11 describes shepherds as greedy and self-serving, 'every one for his gain,' illustrating corrupt leadership neglecting their duties.

questions.question: What invitation do the leaders give in Isaiah 56:12, and what does this reveal about their attitude?
options: Come, let us drink wine and be merry, ignoring responsibility
Come, let us fast and pray for the people
Come, let us build the temple
Come, let us seek justice and peace
questions.correctAnswer: Come, let us drink wine and be merry, ignoring responsibility
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:12 shows leaders inviting indulgence in wine and strong drink with disregard for tomorrow, highlighting irresponsibility and complacency.

questions.question: Which group in Isaiah 56:6 is promised joy and acceptance of their sacrifices on God's altar?
options: Sons of the stranger who keep the sabbath and hold fast to the covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Sons of the stranger who keep the sabbath and hold fast to the covenant
questions.explanation: Verse 6 affirms that foreign converts who serve God faithfully will be brought to His holy mountain and their offerings accepted, indicating inclusion.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 56:4 assures eunuchs that if they keep the sabbath and choose pleasing things, they will be rewarded by the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:4 promises eunuchs who keep the sabbath and choose things pleasing to God a special blessing, emphasizing God's acceptance of marginalized groups.

questions.question: How does the promise to eunuchs in Isaiah 56:5 challenge traditional ancient Near Eastern cultural values?
options: It grants them an everlasting name, surpassing sons and daughters
It excludes them from God's covenant
It commands them to leave the community
It requires them to adopt new customs
questions.correctAnswer: It grants them an everlasting name, surpassing sons and daughters
questions.explanation: In a culture that valued offspring for legacy, Isaiah 56:5's promise to eunuchs of an everlasting name challenges norms by offering divine inclusion and honor.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominent in Isaiah 56:10-11's depiction of watchmen and shepherds, and what is its effect?
options: Metaphor; it criticizes failing leadership through vivid imagery
Simile; it compares leaders to stars
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor; it criticizes failing leadership through vivid imagery
questions.explanation: The passage uses metaphors of blind dogs and greedy shepherds to sharply criticize unfaithful leaders, enhancing the message's impact.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 56:7's phrase 'house of prayer for all people' connect to New Testament themes?
options: It prefigures the inclusion of Gentiles in worship
It refers only to the Jerusalem temple
It is a call for political unity
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures the inclusion of Gentiles in worship
questions.explanation: The verse broadens God's house to all peoples, foreshadowing the New Testament's universal call to worship beyond Israel.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 56:9-12 uses imagery of beasts and dogs to illustrate the negligence and self-interest of Israel's leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: These verses employ animal imagery to depict leaders as blind, greedy, and neglectful, emphasizing their failure to protect and serve the people.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 56 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 56 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What command does the LORD give at the beginning of Isaiah 56 regarding judgment and justice?
options: Keep ye judgment, and do justice
Build an altar for the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Keep ye judgment, and do justice
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:1 commands believers to keep judgment and do justice in anticipation of God's salvation and righteousness being revealed. This aligns with Micah 6:8 which emphasizes doing justice, loving kindness, and walking humbly with God; Proverbs 21:3 which values doing justice and righteousness; and Matthew 23:23 where Jesus upholds justice and mercy as weightier matters of the law.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 56, who is blessed?
options: The man that keepeth the sabbath and doeth no evil
The priest who offers many sacrifices
The prophet who speaks for the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The man that keepeth the sabbath and doeth no evil
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:2 states that the blessed man is the one who keeps the sabbath and refrains from evil. This reflects the biblical principle in Exodus 20:8-11 about the sanctity of the sabbath, and the blessing associated with obedience to God's commands seen in Psalm 1:1-3 and Luke 6:46-49.

questions.question: What assurance is given to the 'son of the stranger' who joins himself to the LORD?
options: He shall not be separated from God's people
He will be excluded from the assembly
questions.correctAnswer: He shall not be separated from God's people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:3 assures that the son of the stranger who joins the LORD is not separated from His people. This emphasizes God's inclusive covenant extending beyond ethnic Israel, consistent with Exodus 12:48-49 on foreigners participating in the Passover, and affirmed in the New Testament by Gentiles being grafted into God's people (Romans 11:17-24).

questions.question: What special promise does God make to eunuchs who keep His sabbaths and hold to His covenant?
options: A place and a name better than sons and daughters
questions.correctAnswer: A place and a name better than sons and daughters
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:5 promises eunuchs who obey God a place and an everlasting name better than sons and daughters, emphasizing God's acceptance and honor of those excluded in society. This reflects God's gracious inclusion noted in Deuteronomy 23:1 and Jesus' affirmation in Matthew 19:12 about those who choose celibacy for the kingdom of heaven.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 56 say about the house of God in relation to prayer?
options: It shall be called an house of prayer for all people
It will be a place of silent meditation
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be called an house of prayer for all people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:7 states that God's house will be a house of prayer for all nations, showing the universal scope of worship and God's invitation beyond Israel. This is echoed in Jeremiah 7:11 and Jesus' citation of this in Matthew 21:13, emphasizing the temple as a place of prayer for all peoples.

questions.question: Who does the LORD say He will gather besides the outcasts of Israel?
options: Others beside those gathered unto Him
questions.correctAnswer: Others beside those gathered unto Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:8 reveals God's eschatological gathering of not only Israel's outcasts but also others, indicating the inclusion of Gentiles and a broader salvation plan. This theme aligns with Acts 15:14 where God calls Gentiles to repentance and Revelation 7:9 depicting a great multitude from every nation.

questions.question: How are the watchmen described in Isaiah 56:10-11?
options: Blind, dumb dogs that cannot bark, greedy, and selfish
Prophets inspired by the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Blind, dumb dogs that cannot bark, greedy, and selfish
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:10-11 condemns the watchmen as blind and mute dogs who are greedy and self-serving, failing in their duty to watch over God's people. This rebuke fits with biblical warnings against false shepherds in Ezekiel 34:2-10, Jeremiah 23:1-2, and Jesus' critique of religious leaders in Matthew 7:15-20.

questions.question: What attitude do the watchmen express toward the future, according to Isaiah 56:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Indifference, desiring to continue indulgence
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:12 describes the watchmen as inviting others to drink wine and strong drink, indifferent to the future and desiring to continue in their indulgence. This contrasts with biblical calls to sober vigilance such as 1 Peter 5:8 and Proverbs 23:29-35, highlighting their spiritual negligence.

questions.question: Which groups are specifically mentioned as being included in God's covenant in Isaiah 56?
options: Eunuchs and sons of the stranger
questions.correctAnswer: Eunuchs and sons of the stranger
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:3-6 includes eunuchs and sons of the stranger as recipients of God's covenant blessings if they keep His sabbath and hold fast to His covenant. This inclusion prefigures the New Testament expansion of God's people to Gentiles (Ephesians 2:11-22) and the acceptance of all who believe (Galatians 3:28).

questions.question: What is the relationship between keeping the sabbath and holding fast to the covenant in Isaiah 56?
options: They are expressions of faithfulness to God
questions.correctAnswer: They are expressions of faithfulness to God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:2, 4-6 link sabbath-keeping and covenant faithfulness as marks of those who please God. This reflects the covenantal faithfulness expected throughout the Old Testament (Exodus 31:13, Nehemiah 13:15-22) and the call to holiness in the New Testament (Hebrews 4:9-10).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 56 reveal about God's character in relation to outcasts and strangers?
options: God is inclusive and gathers all who join Him
God rejects those who are different
questions.correctAnswer: God is inclusive and gathers all who join Him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:3-8 shows God's inclusive nature, gathering outcasts, eunuchs, and foreigners who join Him. This reflects God's universal love and plan of salvation throughout Scripture (Psalm 67:2, Isaiah 49:6, John 10:16, Romans 10:12).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 56 describe the future salvation and righteousness of God?
options: They are near to come and to be revealed
They are only for the priests
questions.correctAnswer: They are near to come and to be revealed
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:1 states that God's salvation is near and His righteousness will be revealed, emphasizing an imminent eschatological fulfillment. This is consistent with prophetic hope in Isaiah 40:5, the advent of Christ in Luke 3:6, and the final revelation of righteousness in Romans 1:17.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'everlasting name' given to eunuchs in Isaiah 56 imply about God's covenant?
options: God grants eternal honor and remembrance
The eunuchs will have many descendants
They will be forgotten by history
Their name will only last a short time
questions.correctAnswer: God grants eternal honor and remembrance
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:5 promises eunuchs an everlasting name, signifying God's covenant includes eternal honor beyond natural lineage. This reflects God's ability to establish a name that endures (Genesis 17:5, Psalm 72:17, Hebrews 11:4).

questions.question: What is the significance of the burnt offerings and sacrifices mentioned in Isaiah 56:7?
options: They will be accepted on God's altar from all who keep the sabbath
They are no longer necessary for salvation
They are only for the priests to perform
They must be offered daily without fail
questions.correctAnswer: They will be accepted on God's altar from all who keep the sabbath
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:7 indicates that offerings from all who keep the sabbath and hold to God's covenant will be accepted, showing God's acceptance of worshippers beyond Israel. This foreshadows the New Testament teaching on acceptable worship in spirit and truth (John 4:23-24) and the priesthood of all believers (1 Peter 2:5).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 56 characterize the behavior of the watchmen in contrast to God's expectations?
options: They are negligent and self-interested rather than watchful and caring
questions.correctAnswer: They are negligent and self-interested rather than watchful and caring
questions.explanation: Isaiah 56:10-11 portrays the watchmen as blind, mute, greedy dogs who look only to their own gain instead of protecting God's people. This contrasts with the biblical ideal of shepherds as faithful caretakers (Ezekiel 34:2-10, John 10:11) and highlights condemnation of corrupt leadership.
